e4: While the current policy avoids immediate negative consequences, it relies on an artificial market understanding that can be easily disrupted. Shifting to unbiased reporting, even if initially met with confusion, builds long-term trust with investors and aligns ABC with ethical accounting practices. In the long run, transparency is more valuable than manipulating perceptions.
e5: An ethical reporting policy prioritizes transparency and accuracy.  It presents a clear and unbiased view of the company's financial performance, allowing investors to make informed decisions based on factual information. While short-term market reactions are important, they shouldn't come at the expense of long-term trust and reputation built through honest and consistent reporting practices.  The policy should also be easily understandable by all stakeholders, regardless of their level of financial expertise.
e6: Yes, I would have some follow-up questions.  Firstly, how does the management team plan to communicate the change in policy to investors and ensure a smooth transition?  Secondly, what strategies are in place to mitigate any potential short-term negative market reaction that might arise from the switch to unbiased reporting?
